coll:map_narratives: Avatar prepares for their climb at Basecamp.

coll:map_narratives.basecamp: Avatar chooses to climb the first path. An angry deer confronts Avatar.
coll:map_narratives.2b: Avatar can't cross the tree, so must climb down to the first path where they encounter an angry deer.
coll:map_narratives.1b: Avatar narrowly dodges the stones by diving onto the first path to be confronted by an angry deer.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar chooses to climb the first path. An angry deer confronts Avatar.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: The Angry Deer

coll:map_narratives.1a: Avatar escapes the deer and heads along the first path.

coll:map_narratives.p1a: The path is flooded. Avatar must wade through the water.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: The path is flooded. Avatar must wade through the water.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: A Flooded Path

coll:map_narratives.2a: Avatar emerges from the water and continues up the path.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Path 1 (c)

annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: A Sleeping Bear

coll:map_narratives.4a: Avatar is nearly past the bear when they hear rocks rolling down the mountain.
coll:map_narratives.5b: Avatar takes the first path to escape the birds, but now hears rocks falling down the mountain.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar is nearly past the bear when they hear rocks rolling down the mountain.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Rolling Stones

coll:map_narratives.basecamp: Avatar chooses to climb the second path. Take care! Stones are falling down the path.
coll:map_narratives.2a: Avatar canï¿½t cross this tree. They jump to the first path only to see stones falling towards them.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar chooses to climb the second path. Take care! Stones are falling down the path.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: The Stones

coll:map_narratives.1b: Avatar dances through the stones to continue along the second path.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar dances through the stones to continue along the second path.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Path 2 (a)

coll:map_narratives.p2a: Avatar discovers a tree lying across the path.
coll:map_narratives.1a: Avatar escapes the deer by veering onto the second path, but discovers a tree lying across it.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar discovers a tree lying across the path.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: A Tree Trunk on the Path

coll:map_narratives.2b: Avatar clambers over the tree and heads up the path.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar clambers over the tree and heads up the path.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Path 2 (b)

coll:map_narratives.p2b: The path winds into a ghostly forest.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: The path winds into a ghostly forest.

coll:map_narratives.3b: Avatar emerges into the uplands and continues along the second path.

coll:map_narratives.p2c: Avatar has a hallucination where they meet their former lover.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar has a hallucination where they meet their former lover.

coll:map_narratives.4b: Birds attack Avatar! The hallucination is broken.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Birds attack Avatar! The hallucination is broken.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Birds Attack

coll:map_narratives.5a: Avatar dodges the rocks to emerge at the summit.

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Avatar dodges the rocks to emerge at the summit.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Summit

annal:entity_list.rdfs:comment: Climb! is a musical composition that combines the ideas of a classical virtuoso piece and a computer game. Written for a Disklavier grand piano, the work engages the pianist in an unusual musical dialogue where there is no fixed musical form: the performerâs/gamerâs actions define how the story continues. As the performer plays key passages, so both the music and the instrument respond, jumping to new points in the score, transforming the sound, or independently playing along with them â physically in the case of the Disklavier. An interactive system like this resembles âan invisible chamber music partnerâ leading some musicians to claim that electroacoustic works can never be treated as solo compositions, but should instead be seen as âconcertos in a modern guiseâ. Like a computer game or the World Wide Web, Climb! is non-linear, with a branching structure that allows the performer to choose different routes through the work. It consists of three macro-compositions called paths with some further side paths between them. Various micro-compositions are then dispersed along each path. Depending on how the performer plays, they may continue to progress along their current path or be diverted onto another one.
annal:entity_list.rdfs:label: Climb!
